fr.sii.ogham.email.builder

Class EmailBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.AbstractParent<MessagingBuilder>
      • fr.sii.ogham.email.builder.EmailBuilder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Builder<ConditionalSender>, Parent<MessagingBuilder>

    public class EmailBuilder
extends AbstractParent<MessagingBuilder>
implements Builder<ConditionalSender>
    Configures how to send Email messages. It allows to:
    • register and configure several sender implementations
    • register and configure several template engines for parsing templates as message content
    • configure handling of missing Email information
    • configure handling of file attachments
    • configure CSS and image handling for Emails with an HTML body
    You can send an Email using the minimal behavior and using JavaMail implementation: 
     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .email()
     .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)   // enable Email sending using JavaMail
       .host("your SMTP server host")
       .port("your SMTP server port")
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .from("sender email address")
   .subject("email subject")
   .content("email body")
   .to("recipient email address"));
    You can also send an Email using a template (using Freemarker for example): The Freemarker template ("email/sample.html.ftl"): 
     <html>
 <head>
 </head>
 <body>
 Email content with variables: ${name} ${value}
 </body>
 </html>
    Then you can send the Email like this: 
     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .email()
     .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)   // enable Email sending using JavaMail
       .host("your SMTP server host")
       .port("your SMTP server port")
       .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerEmailBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .from("sender email address")
   .subject("email subject")
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));

    Instead of explicitly configures SMTP host and port in your code, it could be better to externalize the configuration in a properties file for example (for example a file named "email.properties" in the classpath). The previous example becomes: 

     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("email.properties")
     .and()
   .email()
     .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)   // enable Email sending using JavaMail
       .host("${mail.host}")
       .port("${mail.port}")
       .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerEmailBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .from("sender email address")
   .subject("email subject")
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));
    The content of the file "email.properties": 
     mail.host=your STMP server host
 mail.port=your STMP server port
    Some fields of the Email may be automatically filled by a default value if they are not defined. For example, the sender address could be configured only once for your application: 
     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("email.properties")
     .and()
   .email()
     .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)   // enable Email sending using JavaMail
       .host("${mail.host}")
       .port("${mail.port}")
       .and()
     .autofill()    // enables and configures autofilling
       .from()
         .defaultValueProperty("${email.sender.address}")
         .and()
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerEmailBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email (now the sender address can be omitted)
 service.send(new Email()
   .subject("email subject")
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));
    The content of the file "email.properties": 
     mail.host=your STMP server host
 mail.port=your STMP server port
 email.sender.address=sender email address
    Another very useful automatic filling is for providing the email subject: 
     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = new MessagingBuilder()
   .environment()
     .properties("email.properties")
     .and()
   .email()
     .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)   // enable Email sending using JavaMail
       .host("${mail.host}")
       .port("${mail.port}")
       .and()
     .autofill()    // enables and configures autofilling
       .from()
         .defaultValueProperty("${email.sender.address}")
         .and()
       .subject()
         .htmlTitle(true)    // enables use of html title tag as subject
     .and()
   .template(FreemarkerEmailBuilder.class)  // enable templating using Freemarker
     .classpath()
       .lookup("classpath:")   // search resources/templates in the classpath if a path is prefixed by "classpath:"
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email (now the subject can be omitted)
 service.send(new Email()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));
    Change your template: 
     <html>
 <head>
   <title>email subject - ${name}</title>
 </head>
 <body>
 Email content with variables: ${name} ${value}
 </body>
 </html>
    The obvious advantage is that you have a single place to handle email content (body + subject). There is another benefit: you can also use variables in the subject. There many other configuration possibilities:
    • for configuring Emails with HTML content with a text fallback (useful for smartphones preview of your email for example)
    • for configuring attachments handling
    • for configuring image and css handling

    All the previous examples are provided to understand what can be configured. Hopefully, Ogham provides auto-configuration with a default behavior that fits 95% of usages. This auto-configuration is provided by MessagingConfigurers. Those configurers are automatically applied when using predefined MessagingBuilders like MessagingBuilder.minimal() and MessagingBuilder.standard(). The previous sample using standard configuration becomes: 

     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standad()
   .environment()
     .properties("email.properties")
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));
    The new content of the file "email.properties": 
     mail.host=your STMP server host
 mail.port=your STMP server port
 ogham.email.from=sender email address

    You can also use the auto-configuration for benefit from default behaviors and override some behaviors for your needs: 

     
 // Instantiate the messaging service
 MessagingService service = MessagingBuilder.standard()
   .environment()
     .properties("email.properties")
     .and()
   .email()
     .autofill()
       .from()
         .defaultValueProperty("${email.sender.address}")   // overrides default sender email address property
         .and()
       .and()
     .and()
   .build();
 // send the email
 service.send(new Email()
   .content(new TemplateContent("classpath:email/sample.html.ftl", new SampleBean("foo", 42)))
   .to("recipient email address"));
    The new content of the file "email.properties": 
     mail.host=your STMP server host
 mail.port=your STMP server port
 email.sender.address=sender email address

    • Constructor Detail

      • EmailBuilder

        public EmailBuilder(MessagingBuilder parent,
                    EnvironmentBuilder<?> environmentBuilder)
        Initializes the builder with a parent builder. The parent builder is used when calling AbstractParent.and() method. The EnvironmentBuilder is used to evaluate properties when build() method is called.
        Parameters:
        parent - the parent builder
        environmentBuilder - the configuration for property resolution and evaluation

    • Method Detail

      • attachments

        public AttachmentHandlingBuilder attachments()
        Configures how Attachments are handled. Attachment resolution consists of finding a file:
        • either on filesystem
        • or in the classpath
        • or anywhere else

        To identify which resolution to use, each resolution is configured to handle one or several lookups prefixes. For example, if resolution is configured like this: 

         
 .string()
   .lookup("string:", "s:")
   .and()
 .file()
   .lookup("file:")
   .and()
 .classpath()
   .lookup("classpath:", "");
        Then you can reference a file that is in the classpath like this: 
         "classpath:foo/bar.pdf"

        Resource resolution is also able to handle path prefix and suffix. The aim is for example to have a folder that contains all templates. The developer then configures a path prefix for the folder. He can also configure a suffix to fix extension for templates. Thanks to those prefix/suffix, templates can now be referenced by the name of the file (without extension). It is useful to reference a template independently from where it is in reality (classpath, file or anywhere else) . Switching from classpath to file and conversely can be done easily (by updating the lookup). For example: 

         .classpath().lookup("classpath:").pathPrefix("foo/").pathSuffix(".html");
 
 resourceResolver.getResource("classpath:bar");
        The real path is then foo/bar.pdf.

        This implementation is used by MessagingBuilder for general configuration. That configuration may be inherited (applied to other resource resolution builders).

        Detection of the mimetype of each attachment is not directly configured here. Attachment handling depends totally on the sender implementation. Some implementations will require that a mimetype is provided (JavaMail for example) while other implementations doesn't need it (SendGrid for example).

        Returns:
        the builder to configure attachment handling

      • autofill

        public AutofillEmailBuilder autofill()
        Configures how Ogham will add default values to the Email if some information is missing. If sender address is missing, a default one can be defined in configuration properties. If recipient address is missing, a default one can be defined in configuration properties. If subject is missing, a default one can be defined either:
        • In HTML title
        • In first line of text template
        • Using a default value defined in configuration properties
        For example: 
         
 builder
  .autofill()
    .subject()
      .defaultValueProperty("${ogham.email.subject}")
      .htmlTitle(true)
      .text("${ogham.email.subject-first-line-prefix}", "Subject:")
            .and()
    .from()
            .defaultValueProperty("${ogham.email.from}", "${mail.smtp.from}")
            .and()
    .to()
            .defaultValueProperty("${ogham.email.to}")
            .and()
    .cc()
            .defaultValueProperty("${ogham.email.cc}")
            .and()
    .bcc()
            .defaultValueProperty("${ogham.email.bcc}")
        Returns:
        the builder to configure autofilling of Email

      • css

        public CssHandlingBuilder css()
        CSS handling consists of defining how CSS are inlined in the email. Inlining CSS means that CSS styles are loaded and applied on the matching HTML nodes using the style HTML attribute. For example: 
         .css()
   .inline()
     .jsoup()
        Enables inlining of CSS styles using Jsoup utility.
        Returns:
        the builder to configure css handling

      • images

        public ImageHandlingBuilder images()
        Image handling consists of defining how images are inlined in the email:
        • Either inlining directly in the HTML content by enconding image into base64 string
        • Or attaching the image to the email and referencing it using a Content-ID (CID)
        • Or no inlining
        For example: 
         .images()
   .inline()
     .attach()
       .cid()
         .generator(new SequentialIdGenerator())
         .and()
       .and()
     .base64();
        Enables both inlining modes (attaching images and encoding in base64). By default, attaching is used if nothing is specified in the HTML. You can also explicitly specify which mode to using the ogham-inline-mode attribute (see ImageHandlingBuilder.inline() for more information).
        Returns:
        the builder to configure images handling

      • template

        public <T extends Builder<? extends TemplateParser>> T template(Class<T> builderClass)
        Registers and configures a TemplateParser through a dedicated builder. For example: 
         .register(ThymeleafEmailBuilder.class)
     .detector(new ThymeleafEngineDetector());

        Your Builder may implement VariantBuilder to handle template Variants (used for MultiTemplateContent that provide a single path to templates with different extensions for example).

        Your Builder may also implement DetectorBuilder in order to indicate which kind of templates your TemplateParser is able to parse. If your template parse is able to parse any template file you are using, you may not need to implement DetectorBuilder.

        In order to be able to keep chaining, you builder instance may provide a constructor with two arguments:

        • The type of the parent builder (&lt;P&gt;)
        • The EnvironmentBuilder instance
        If you don't care about chaining, just provide a default constructor.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the builder
        Parameters:
        builderClass - the builder class to instantiate
        Returns:
        the builder to configure the implementation

      • customSender

        public EmailBuilder customSender(MessageSender sender)
        Registers a custom message sender implementation.

        If your custom implementation is annotated by one or several of:

        • RequiredClass
        • RequiredProperty
        • RequiredClasses
        • RequiredProperties
        Then if condition evaluation returns true, your implementation will be used. If you provide several annotations, your implementation will be used only if all conditions are met (and operator).

        If your custom implementation implements ActivableAtRuntime, and the provided condition evaluation returns true, then your implementation will be used. See MessageConditions to build your condition.

        If neither annotations nor implementation of ActivableAtRuntime is used, then your custom implementation will be always used. All other implementations (even standard ones) will never be used.

        Parameters:
        sender - the sender to register
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • sender

        public <T extends Builder<? extends MessageSender>> T sender(Class<T> builderClass)
        Registers and configures sender through a dedicated builder. For example: 
         .sender(JavaMailBuilder.class)
     .host("localhost");

        If your custom builder is annotated by one or several of:

        • RequiredClass
        • RequiredProperty
        • RequiredClasses
        • RequiredProperties
        Then if condition evaluation returns true, your built implementation will be used. If you provide several annotations, your built implementation will be used only if all conditions are met (and operator).

        If your custom builder implements ActivableAtRuntime, and the provided condition evaluation returns true, then your built implementation will be used. See MessageConditions to build your condition.

        If neither annotations nor implementation of ActivableAtRuntime is used, then your built implementation will be always used. All other implementations (even standard ones) will never be used.

        In order to be able to keep chaining, you builder instance may provide a constructor with one argument with the type of the parent builder (EmailBuilder). If you don't care about chaining, just provide a default constructor.

        Your builder may return null when calling Builder.build(). In this case it means that your implementation can't be used due to current environment. Your implementation is then not registered.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the builder
        Parameters:
        builderClass - the builder class to instantiate
        Returns:
        the builder to configure the implementation

      • build

        public ConditionalSender build()
        Description copied from interface: Builder
        Instantiate and configures the instance.

        build in interface Builder<ConditionalSender>
        Returns:
